explanation: The report is correct. With the provided macro definitions LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg) expands to ((void)lfs->cfg, 0). The comma operator evaluates its left operand ((void)lfs->cfg) at runtime and then yields 0. The left operand performs no observable action (it merely discards the value of lfs->cfg), so its execution has no effect on program behaviour; removing that sub‑expression would not change observable behaviour. By MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 (“Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code”), that evaluated no‑op is dead code. (Caveat: if evaluating cfg had side effects — e.g. reading from volatile memory or invoking something with side effects in another build configuration — then it would not be dead; given the shown definitions it is a no‑op and thus a violation.)
